intro: Pleconax pamphylica, commonly known as the Pamphylian pleconax, is a flowering plant native to the Mediterranean region. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its aromatic foliage. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30 to 60 centimeters, with finely divided leaves and small white or greenish flowers. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, often found in rocky or gravelly habitats. Due to its ornamental value and medicinal properties, it is occasionally cultivated in gardens and traditional herbal practices.
